title: The Web Planet
dialogue_triumphs: Hetra describes digging in one of Doctor Who's few attempts to show alien thought patterns: 'A silent wall. We must make mouths in it with our weapons, then it will speak more light.'
dialogue_disasters: Doctor to Ian: 'Whatever power has taken hold of the TARDIS has taken your pen.'
Asking the Animus to lower its communication helmet: 'Drop this hairdryer, or whatever it is.'
goofs: Ian Thompson's decision to play Hetra with a stilted French bandit accent is interesting. 'Zarbiiiiiii!'
A Zarbi hits a camera with an audible thump in episode three, and a Zarbi abdomen clangs on the studio floor.
One of the imprisoned Menoptra, judging by its gestures, is merrily chatting to a Zarbi guard.
The Zarbi are scared of tiny dead spiders.
In episode two, when Hroonda is killed, his wings fall off.
For five seconds in episode two, nothing appears to be happening in 'Web HQ'.
In episode four, as Ian is buried in the rock fall, someone can be heard laughing.
Shadows are cast on the sky through much of the story.
Barbara gives Vicki an aspirin when she asks for a sedative.

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.description: The main protagonist of the series, a Time Lord who travels through time and space.
continuity_notes.current_status: Exploring Vortis and confronting the Animus

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor's Ring
continuity_notes.description: A ring with special properties, linked to the TARDIS and capable of various functions.
continuity_notes.current_status: Used to open TARDIS doors and control Zarbi when connected to TARDIS systems

continuity_notes.name: Vicki
continuity_notes.description: A companion of the Doctor with acute hearing and advanced education for her age.
continuity_notes.current_status: Traveling with the Doctor and exploring Vortis

continuity_notes.name: Ian Chesterton
continuity_notes.description: A companion of the Doctor and former teacher at Coal Hill School.
continuity_notes.current_status: Exploring Vortis and helping confront the Animus

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time and space machine, capable of various functions beyond transportation.
continuity_notes.current_status: Under influence of the Animus, with some systems compromised

continuity_notes.name: Menoptra
continuity_notes.description: Butterfly-like inhabitants of Vortis, formerly worshipped at temples of light.

continuity_notes.name: Zarbi
continuity_notes.description: Ant-like creatures of Vortis, formerly used as cattle by the Menoptra.

continuity_notes.name: Animus
continuity_notes.description: A parasitic entity that absorbs energy and seeks to invade Earth.
continuity_notes.current_status: Controlling Vortis and attempting to expand its influence

technobabble: The TARDIS can be remotely controlled by mental power
roots: White's The Sword in the Stone
The Outer Limits episode 'The Zanti Misfits'
links: Barbara wears the gold bracelet that Nero gave her ('The Romans').

locations.name: Vortis
locations.description: A planet in the Isop galaxy, home to the Menoptra and Zarbi, now under the influence of the Animus.
locations.current_status: Controlled by the Animus, orbited by Pictos

future_history: The story is set in the far future, as the Animus plans to 'take from man his mastery of space'.
additional_notes: Ian uses his tie as a belt. The story features ambitious attempts to portray alien environments and thought patterns.
bottom_line: Imaginative, ambitious, and, by modern standards, slow and silly-looking. It's hard to judge a story that, at the time, was astonishing but has aged so badly. Effects age faster than anything else, so basing a story on them is risky. The insect gestures, odd speech patterns and use of camera filters are all sincere attempts to suggest the alien, applaudable in a series where aliens are usually Nazis with make-up. You've got to appreciate lofty ambitions.
